reviewText: I was introduced to Tyler Perry's work by a friend. So I have seen Madea's Witness Protection, Madea Goes to Jail and now this play and Diary of a Mad Black Woman( play). I love the character of Madea which just lets it all out verbally, without holding back. Very funny to watch. I am not into musicals, but find that by the middle of the first play I watched, this seemed normal. I even liked the singing, much of which is God oriented. This play has some touching moments too. Mr. Tyler Perry was abused earlier in life and had been homeless, yet his message is one of hope, love and forgiveness. This guy has avoided the pitfalls of Hollywood too. Give him a try, you will be hooked. He is a genius.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought Madea's Class Reunion was a pretty funny play. I loved the storyline and all of its subplots, I liked how the play incorporated flashbacks during some songs, I liked how crazy and insane the bellhop/bartender character was, I liked the parts where Madea started singing songs of different artists (esp. Whitney Houston and Missy Elliott) and I liked the nacho joke. That's just grazing the surface of what I liked about the play. Overall, I thought it was very entertaining and I give Tyler Perry one thumb up. The only thing that's holding me back from giving two thumbs up is that I was kinda let down that there wasn't enough Madea in the play. She didn't even show up until the second act and plus the whole concept of her, Mr. Brown and their two other classmates that aren't either dead or in retirement homes coming together for a class reunion kinda got lost in all of the other subplots going on. I mean we got a man who's cheating on his wife with another woman, a woman who's scared to stand up to her boyfriend who's physically abusing her and a married couple who's future together seems hopeless due the wife cheating on her husband. With everything else going on, there wasn't much left for the class reunion plot, which was supposed to be the main focus.
summary: Pretty funny, but not enough Madea

reviewText: I like  his plays better than his movies except for the family that preys ... and Good deeds(those I loved!)  Because I hated the others,especially the "why did I get married ones",  they were almost the same as whats done in the dark, meet the Browns, family reunion and the diary of a mad black woman.  Unless he goes back to making more and better plays, I will continue to look for other than his and others that makes plays and they are out there.  Out of respect for Tyler, I won't say who they are.  Tyler has done a lot for plays, people that wouldn't normally go to plays go now and they really enjoy live performances. This last movie, I didn't even finish watching it I was highly disappointed, the witness protection,  Tyler really?
summary: One of the first Tyler Perry plays I liked

reviewText: Tyler Perry has done it again, another big hit! This play is laugh-at-loud entertainment from start to finish. You never know what to expect next from Madea, a character that can never be forgotten. As funny as she may be, there's always a lesson to be learned with her charm and wisdom. Tyler Perry's talent shines very bright through Madea. One funny woman who has it all, and can make you laugh over-and-over again. There's never a dull moment when Madea has entered the room. Fun-filled right to the end, and Very Enjoyable. Highly Recommended!

reviewText: I love Tyler as the bellhop/bartender. One of his funniest roles. The story line is also one that rings true and hits the mark. You can laugh, and still walk away with something. I get his work. I understand the message and delivery. Thanks Tyler for bringing the laughter and sometimes tears.

reviewText: If you enjoy Tyler Perry plays and/or if you are entertained by Madea, you will enjoy this play.  I really like Willie's character, but I am glad it is not present for the whole play.  At the same time, I am kind of glad that Madea's character isn't in the full play.  Some of the familiar characters are back and a little more 3 dimensional.  There is a variety of new characters, but not too many that any seem unnecessary or redundant.  The story line continues from other plays, which adds a great series feel.  Funny from start to finish.

reviewText: It would be difficult for me to write an objective review. I love Madea and haven't seen one movie that I didn't appreciate. Several life lessons, lots of wisdom - - and most importantly LAUGHS! Sometimes life throws us a curve and we can sit in our sorrow and wallow or suck it up and deal. Madea gives us great advice for getting over it and moving on with a sense of humor! Recommend this movie for anyone!

reviewText: After watching the movie by Tyler Perry, THE DIARY OF A MAD BLACK WOMAN,  I wanted to watch all of the plays that Tyler Perry had written and acted in as well.  MADEA'S CLASS REUNION was the very first play that I watched of the collection. Boy was it a good introduction to a wonderful collection of plays.When I watched this play, I wasn't expecting it to be so good.  Not only was there a lot of laughs but there was great gospel singing, acting, and a Christian "tonality" to the play.  While the movie THE DIARY OF A MAD BLACK WOMAN somewhat exploited this Christian tone, it didn't do it to the degree that any of Perry's stage plays did.  Here a prostitute fights for her life with a husband who abuses her (and is a pimp), at a hotel, an elderly lady who cleans the rooms is fired by a manager who isn't Christian but ends up becoming the manager of the hotel.  I would tell you more, but you must experience this master work for yourself.  I will tell you that Madea is "funny as h***, I ain't lying" (one of her famous lines throughout the Tyler Perry series).  5 stars.
summary: A Wonderful Play with a wonderful Christian message
